ref.mixed-citation: David Parker (Ethics)
Budick [Edna "passively, passionlessly, dissolve[s] and disap- pear[s]" (123)] 123
Delbanco ["She has lost her fight against ennui, and what is worse, she knows it" (104)] 104
Gilmore ["Edna is trapped not solely by circumstances but also by her own unconscious assent to the val- ues of her society" (83)] 83
Harris [" ... she is unable to formulate a viable selfhood" (206)] 206
Hochman [The Awakening is "pervaded by a concern with modes of exaltation and fusion that ultimately make emergence impossible for protagonists" (230)] 230
Huf ["In isolation her battle can only fail" (79)] 79
Dorothy H. Jacobs ["No longer the dupe ... she follows a sort of symbolic logic akin to Oedipus's blinding the eyes that failed to see who he was" (94)]
Kearns ["Edna systematically nullifies herself as she nullifies others... " (77)] 77
Rowe ["the pathos of The Awakening is just this: the self has become a character in a melodrama" (141)] 141
Ryan [Edna is "strong enough to rebel, but too weak to sustain herself against the forces of nature and society" (268)] 268
Skaggs [" ... Edna finds that her life must be lived within socioeconomic and biological boundaries as unyielding as the walls around any penitentiary" (83)] 83
Showalter (see below)
Walker ["Edna drifts into death because she does nothing to stop it" (103)] 103
Wolff ["So, Edna has failed" (195)] 195
Wolkenfeld [Edna's "defeat and regression" is "rooted... in a romantic incapacity to accommo- date ... to the limitations of reality" (215)] 215
Emily Toth (209-30) 209
The Awakening
"Edna's suicide as a spiritual triumph but a social defeat" (39)
DuPlessis ["Death becomes a symbolic protest against the reproduc- tion of a respectable female and the connivances of a respectable community" (16) 16
Ewell [" ... in Edna's triumph ... lies a revolutionary image of the dream of female selfhood" (165) 165
Levine ["Edna perceives death beckoning as a masterful and transcendent lover offering a final consummating sleep" (78-79) 78
Helen Taylor [" ... Edna's suicide does symbolically 'explode' codes in a revolutionary moment... "(207) 207
Seyersted ["Apparently defeated" Edna nevertheless achieves "a victory of self- knowledge and authenticity as she fully becomes herself" (Biography 194)] 194

Huf along with Gilbert and Gubar (1:182-83) 182

Mary Catherine Bateson's Composing a Life
Bateson
Composing a Life
Nina Baym for a very similar judgment: The Awakening is "not so much a feminist work as an individual and indecisive meditation on feminist themes, resisting translation into ideology" (xxxix)
Giorecelli [Edna reaches for a transcendence "that abandons self... [in] reaching out for an attainment of more self"]

LeBlanc [Edna attains the so-called "lesbian moment" when "borders are dissolved between 'self and other, subject and object, lover and beloved,' reader and narrative. We are invited into the text, into the water, into the mind of the metaphorical lesbian, as she and her lover enter each other and become one" (305-06)] 305
Seidel, for an equivalent meta- physical yearning: Edna's "birth as a new self creates a life that lives for only a few moments before the foam that gave birth to it softly annihilates it" (235) 235
